questions.question_text: Due to security threats, your security team would like to immediately prevent any apps on a ChromeOS device from being able to use USB devices. How can you as the admin implement this security practice as quickly and efficiently as possible?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
I’m cool with C, unless someone’s got a better take.

choices.D: Create a blocklist, add apps that use USB permissions, and allow users to “request” apps that are not approved
choices.A: Create a blocklist and add apps that use USB permission
choices.C: Create an allowlist and add apps that do not need USB permission
choices.B: Block apps by using the “Block apps by permissions settings" which will allow you to select “USB” as permission type to block

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
I checked the docs, and A seems right.

questions.question_text: Your organization is buying new ChromeOS devices to replace older devices. You are receiving these devices and need to dispose of them responsibly. What should you do to each of these devices before disposing of them?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Leaning toward B, but open to other ideas.

choices.C: Force devices to automatically re-enroll after wiping
choices.A: Add a disabled device return instruction message
choices.D: Allow users into your organization to enroll new or re-enroll existing devices

questions.question_text: Your security department wants to mitigate the risk of data loss in the case of stolen equipment. As a ChromeOS Administrator, you want to ensure that your ChromeOS devices will be able to stay enterprise-managed. What should you do?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
I’ve got a hunch it’s A.

questions.question_text: Your company's network team reports Wi-Fi issues with certain ChromeOS devices. To troubleshoot, you will reproduce the problem but also need to collect network logs. How are you going to proceed?

choices.B: From chrome://network, use the “Network Logs” tab and select the policies.json, all logs files collected by debugd, and all Chrome log files.
choices.A:
From chrome://network, use the “Network Logs” tab, select the “Wi-Fi debug” mode, open a new tab and reproduce the issue.
Once completed, go back to the original tab, then export the “system_logs.txt" file and all log files collected by debugd.
choices.C: From chrome://network, use the “Network Logs” tab, select the “Wi-fi debug" mode, then export the “system_logs.txt” file and all log files collected by debugd.
choices.D: From the Chrome Browser, use the “chrome://system" page and check the “wifi_status_no_anonymize" attribute
